title: #206 – Exercising for longevity: strength, stability, zone 2, zone 5, and more
content: In this special episode of The Drive, we have pulled together a variety of clips from previous podcasts about exercise to help listeners understand this topic more deeply, as well as to identify previous episodes which may be of interest. In this episode, Peter discusses his framework for exercise, what he’s really optimizing for, and how to train today to be prepared for a good life at age 100. He describes the importance of strength and stability, and why deadlifting is an important tool to consider for longevity. Additionally, he details why training in zone 2 and zone 5 is important, gives a primer on VO2 max, and describes the most effective ways to engage in those types of exercise. Finally, Peter reveals his current exercise routine. Subscribe on: APPLE PODCASTS | RSS | GOOGLE | OVERCAST | STITCHER The Peter Attia Drive #206 - Exercising for longevity: strength, stability, zone 2, zone 5, and more The Peter Attia Drive         The Peter Attia Drive         #206 - Exercising for longevity: strength, stability, zone 2, zone 5, and more           #206 - Exercising for longevity: strength, stability, zone 2, zone 5, and more           More Speed: 50% Speed: 75% Speed: Normal Speed: 125% Speed: 150% Speed: 175% Speed: Double Speed: Triple Back 15 seconds Forward 60 seconds More more Speed: 50% Speed: 75% Speed: Normal Speed: 125% Speed: 150% Speed: 175% Speed: Double Speed: Triple Back 15 seconds Forward 60 seconds Currently Playing Download More We discuss: What is Peter optimizing for with his exercise? [3:00]; (from AMA #12) Preparing for a good life at age 100: Training for the “Centenarian Decathlon” [6:00]; (from AMA #5) The importance of preserving strength and muscle mass as we age [21:45]; (from AMA #27) The value of deadlifts for stability and longevity when done properly [27:30]; (from episode #103) The importance of zone 2 aerobic training [35:45]; (from episode #103) The most effective ways to engage in zone 2 exercise [40:00]; (from AMA #19) Zone 5 training and VO2 max [44:15]; (from AMA #21) A primer on VO2 max [52:00]; (from episode #151) Stability—the cornerstone upon which all exercise and movement relies [1:03:00]; (from AMA #12) Peter’s current exercise routine [1:07:45]; (from AMA #32) More. In this episode, Rhonda provides her latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's more Speed: 50% Speed: 75% Speed: Normal Speed: 125% Speed: 150% Speed: 175% Speed: Double Speed: Triple Back 15 seconds Forward 60 seconds Currently Playing Download More .cls-1 { fill-rule: evenodd; } Sort oldest first Sort newest first 293 Play #252 ‒ Latest insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting | Rhonda Patrick, Ph.D. 292 Play The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health | Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D. (#51 rebroadcast) 291 Play #251 - AMA #46: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more 290 Play #250 ‒ Training principles for longevity | Andy Galpin, Ph.D. (PART II) 289 Play #249 ‒ How the brain works, Andrew’s fascinating backstory, improving scientific literacy, and more | Andrew Huberman, Ph.D. 288 Play #248 ‒ OUTLIVE book: A behind-the-scenes look into the writing of this book, motivation, main themes, and more 287 Play #247 ‒ Preventing cardiovascular disease: the latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more | Ethan Weiss, M.D. 286 Play #246 - AMA #45:  Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent 285 Play #245 ‒ Overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life | Lewis Howes 284 Play #244 ‒ The history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more | Siddhartha Mukherjee Previous page 1 of 30 Next page Back to playlist view Episode Details View the Show Notes Page for This Episode Become a Member to Receive Exclusive Content Sign Up to Receive Peter’s Weekly Newsletter Rhonda Patrick, Ph.D., is a scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition who translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights on her podcast, Found My Fitness. In this episode, Rhonda provides her latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. She also touches on cancer risk including the relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer. Additionally, Rhonda explains her new focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how her perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding. We discuss: Alzheimer’s disease: Rhonda’s evolved thinking on neurodegenerative diseases [2:30]; The breakdown of the blood-brain barrier in neurodegenerative disease [8:45]; An explanation for the observation that type 2 diabetes increases risk of Alzheimer’s disease [15:45]; The role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration [19:45]; Comparing the preventable nature of type 2 diabetes, atherosclerosis, cancer, and dementia [32:15]; Blood pressure: an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk [35:15]; Rhonda’s outlook on “precision medicine” as it pertains to one’s genetic predispositions [38:45]; Possible mechanisms by which exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer’s disease [45:45]; Building your aerobic pyramid: neurobiological effects of exercise, benefits of lactate peaks, and more [53:45]; Maximizing mitochondrial biogenesis: alternative training approaches and strategies [58:45]; Possible brain benefits of sauna, and Rhonda’s personal protocol [1:09:30]; The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk [1:15:30]; How exercise may reduce the risk of cancer [1:20:30]; The overarching impact of exercise on health, and the importance of focusing the factors that matter most [1:33:15]; Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health [1:37:15]; Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits [1:42:30]; The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength [1:46:30]; How to get enough of the right kind of protein in your diet [2:05:15]; Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward [2:12:15]; How Rhonda’s views have shifted on diet and exercise [2:15:30]; How to follow Rhonda’s work and more about the benefits of lactate for the brain [2:21:00]; and More. Connect With Peter on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and YouTube Download Download Subscribe Subscribe Share Share § Show Notes*Notes from intro: We realize there are a lot of new listeners who haven’t had the chance to listen to all of our older episodes, so for this week we’re experimenting with a different format We put together a variety of clips from previous podcasts that discuss exercise and Peter’s framework for exercise The links at the end of the show notes direct you to what portion of previous episodes are featured in this podcast We put these clips in order of what we think is the best way to listen Peter will provide some commentary before (and in between) each clip Our hope is that this will allow you to understand this topic better, and also help identify some previous episodes you may be interested in listening to to dive deeper The first set of clips looks at what Peter is optimizing for with his exercise, and why he thinks training for the Centenarian Decathlon is so important Some of these clips are from AMAs, so if you’re not a subscriber, you’ll be able to get an idea of what we cover on those episodes Additionally, for the stability and DNS content clips (in our episodes with Beth Lewis and Michael Rintala), we actually filmed instructional videos of them showing how to do these various exercises As this is the first time we’re doing this, please let us know if this is something you like, would want more of, and how we can make it better   What is Peter optimizing for with his exercise? [3:00] From episode #92 – AMA #12: Strategies for longevity (which don’t require a doctor); discussed from [30:30] – [33:45] Peter is looking at exercise through the lens of longevity, not performance The difference is important If your goal was to break 2 hours and 40 minutes on the Chicago Marathon next year, the training required would be totally different from that needed to maximize longevity Longevity is a very difficult performance goal When you start to look into the far recesses of amazing physical performance, training would be very specific for that This is not what Peter is discussing Training for this type of performance is generally not collinear with longevity and at times they can be outright orthogonal  So this is the difference between something being in-line with (collinear) or at-odds with (orthogonal) Exceptional physical performances requires maximum cardiac output, just beneath VO2 max  This level of performance and training puts an amazing strain on the body While this is better than sitting on the couch all day, it is past the point of optimizing longevity returns This comes at some longevity cost relative to training at a lower energy system Why training for the “Centenarian Decathlon” is so important  This podcast is geared toward this “Centenarian Decathlon” “This is the idea of being the most kick-ass 90-year old possible”‒ Peter Attia This is based on 2 energy systems: 1 – Strength and stability 2 – Low-end aerobic energy system (which is zone 2, we’ll talk about that in a moment) which is punctuated with brief bursts of zone 5 These energy systems matter because this is generally where life takes place “Life is zone 1, zone 2, and zone 5”‒ Peter Attia By training in zone 2 and zone 5 (with much more focus on zone 2), we’re preparing metabolically and structurally for longevity   Preparing for a good life at age 100: Training for the “Centenarian Decathlon” [6:00] From episode #50 – AMA #5: calcium scores, Centenarian Decathlon, exercise, muscle glycogen, keto, and more; discussed from [18:15] – [33:45] What does Peter wish he incorporated into his exercise at age 25 to be in this race for the gold medal in the “Centenarian Decathlon”? For most people, a system of the body is going to fail first Some people die suddenly when their mind and body are fine; they are an exception to this discussion For many people their mind fails first, cognition is taken from them and then eventually they die or their body breaks down For most people, the decline of mind and body, and the burden of disease occurs as the body fails first This prompted Peter to think about how to mitigate the decline / fail of the body He engaged in backcasting (instead of forecasting), to think of what he wants to do when he is 100 and work backwards from that to determine what to do today at age 45 (or any age) He borrowed the term backcasting from Annie Duke who wrote Thinking in Bets  See episode #60 with Annie Duke This led to the question‒ What do I have to physically be able to do to be satisfied with my life at 100 years old?  He thought about how old his kids would be when he is 100, and how old will their kids be He realized at this age, his grandkids will have kids When Peter is 100, he will likely have great-grandchildren that are between the ages of 1-8 What will Peter want to be able to do at 100 to be happy? He doesn’t want to be bedridden with disease He wants to retain his cognitive faculties  There are lots of physical activities he want to be able to do Shoot a bow and arrow Exercise (he enjoys it) Activities of daily living are important Things he would want to do with his great-grandkids when they are 1, 3, 4, 5, etc. Be able to drop into a squat position and pick up a child that weighs 30 lbs Be able to get up off the floor using a single point of support, such as just 1 arm Be able to lift something that weighs 30 lbs over his head; this is about the weight of his carry-on suitcase Be able to get out of a pool without a ladder Be able to walk up 3 flights of stairs with 10 lbs of groceries in each hand He made a list of 18 things‒ this became his centenarian decathlon (even though a decathlon is only 10 things) He asked‒ What are physical tasks that will approximate the things he wants to be able to do for daily living at age 100?  What exercises will be useful to prepare to do the things Peter wants to do at age 100? A 30 lb goblet squat can approximate picking up a 30-lb kid who comes running at you Figure 1. The goblet squat. Image credit: xbodyconcepts.com Working back from 100 years old, and realizing there is going to be a decline with age, Peter can set goals for age 80, age 60, and today Peter’s training today centers around the goals of what he wants to do when he is 100-years-old He doesn’t do any training related to racing or competing in anything (not that this is bad) Peter was not thinking of longevity and life at 100 years of age as a 25-years-old Peter’s framework for thinking about exercise for longevity has 4 components [13:45] 1 – Stability 2 – Strength 3 – Aerobic performance 4 – Anaerobic output Each of his 18 goals (for his Centenarian decathlon) touch on at least 1 of these items in this framework; some touch on more than 1 The goblet squat requires both strength and stability Walking up 3 flights of stairs with 10 lbs of groceries in each hand is on the threshold of aerobic/ anaerobic output and also requires strength Stability is where most people first begin to fail This begins around the time that children start school Peter has noticed that young children are so good at stability‒ the way they squat, the way they move is so natural The field of dynamic neuromuscular stabilization is based on this principle that there are 13-14 movements that are innate to us By the time we are about 1.5-years-old, we do them all perfectly Then it’s basically all downhill from there Decline of stability is accelerated by school, once you start sitting We lose the ability to maintain tension through our pelvic floor and throughout our entire core The core describing the: diaphragm, obliques, transversalis fascia, and the entire pelvic floor Peter recommends: Spend as much time as possible working on static stability then dynamic stability Incorporate these principles into what you are doing strength-wise At the age of 25, you can do a lot of exercises incorrectly and get away with it But correct form is very important in the long run  Peter thinks he’s always squatted and deadlift somewhat incorrectly He’s never fully engaged his pelvic floor doing those He got away with doing those incorrectly for a long time but now realize the damage that has occurred as a result An anecdote‒ Peter’s breathing squat routine from high school: It’s an amazing routine, but he doesn’t know if he recommends it  In high school he lifted 6 days a week, 3 hours a day Once a week they did a routine of breathing squats Take your best 10-rep weight (a weight that you would fail with at 10-reps), load it on your back and do a squat (1 rep) Go down and up at your normal cadence  At the top of the squat, you take 3 of the deepest breaths you can take  Each breath taking 10 seconds for a total of 30 sec Breathe in for 5 sec, breathe out for 5 sec (x3) After taking these 3 deep breaths at the top of the squat, do another squat  Continue this routine for a total of 20 reps This set takes 10 minutes The only thing Peter has done since that rivals this degree discomfort of is an airbike tabata  Peter describes this squat routine, “as one of these knuckle-head things we got out of our bodybuilder magazines (powerlifting magazines), and the idea was that nothing would stimulate more strength and growth than that activity”  It worked Over the course of 1 year doing this, he added over 100 lbs to his squat And that was starting at a level where he was already pretty strong This workout was so painful that he would start getting uptight the day before This relates to “super slow” or slow training‒ lifting slow and accumulating time under tension ~90 seconds On of the proponents of this is Doug McGuff who wrote Body by Science  90 seconds feels like an eternity Until you time yourself lifting, you don’t realize how little time is spent under tension Peter’s memory from this breathing squats workout is that his upper body hurt as much as his lower body There are a lot of on-going centenarian studies (listed below) and Bob wonders how many of these centenarians could do this decathlon‒ none of them The Einstein one in NY of Ashkenazi Jews‒ The Longevity Genes Project at Albert Einstein College of Medicine’s Institute for Aging Research Thomas Perls study has an aggregate of different ethnicities [the New England Centenarian Study] Peter comments on anyone who is a centenarian today This is an extreme statement, but Peter thinks that anyone who is a centenarian today lived this long because of their exceptional genes They haven’t hacked their way there Most of them haven’t done anything different (better/ worse) than their peers On average today’s centenarians tend to smoke more, exercise less, and eat worse than their peers “What we’re talking about (people our age) is… hacking our way to centenarians”‒ Peter Attia This is very deliberate This is a new model to force your way to become a centenarian and will require deliberate attention around what you mind and body are doing   The importance of preserving strength and muscle mass as we age [21:45] From episode #176 – AMA #27: The importance of muscle mass, strength, and cardiorespiratory fitness for longevity; discussed from [58:00] – [1:03:30] How much lean mass are people losing over time?  What is aging robbing you of as time goes on? The lowest rate of decline in lean mass (shown by studies) is 1-2% per year after age 50; see the table below Between ages 20-80, this is a loss of 35-40% The strength decline may be even greater Some studies show 4% loss of strength per year Figure 2.  Loss of lean muscle and strength over time.  Image credit: MLTJ 2013 This is difficult to put in context when you understand what compounding does “If you have the aspiration of kicking ass when your 85, you can’t afford to be average when you’re 50”‒ Peter Attia You’ve got to have cardiorespiratory fitness, strength, and even muscle mass They looked at men and women leg strength versus grip strength (a leg extension and a grip exercise) The leg strength was measured in Newton meters (Nm) doing leg extensions The grip strength was measured in kilograms The average age of participating men was 54 and for women it was 53  They were followed prospectively for 5-6 years  This study looked at all-cause mortality The change in men’s leg strength (shown in panel 1 of the figure below) is not subtle This shows that the weaker one is, the quicker the decline in strength  For every 0.2 unit reduction in strength per ct area they saw a significant increase in mortality  Strength was normalized for muscle size Muscle area was measured by computed tomography (CT) scan, to look at cross-sectional area Lean tissue mass was determined using DEXA (dual energy-x-ray absorptiometry) They took that normalized unit of strength per CT area and observed when it was reduced by 0.2 units, there was a 26%  When muscle area was measured by DEXA, a 0.2 reduction in strength was associated with a 39% increase in mortality Even without this normalization the result is the same Grip strength was normalized by a DEXA arm measurement  Reduced grip strength was associated with a 23% increase in mortality  These were statistically significant results; shown in the figure below For women, there was a larger confidence interval Figure 3.  Kaplan-Meier survival curves for strength grouped by standard deviation.  Image credit: The Journals of Gerontology Series a 2006 Peter finds the table below (Figure 4) to be an easier way to appreciate the statistical relevance of their findings  Peter’s takeaway: Normalizing strength by size of muscle and prospectively following people we see a trend‒ strength is the more important parameter  Figure 4. (Table 4) Specific torque-mortality risk per standard deviation in men and women.  Image credit: The Journals of Gerontology series a 2006   The value of deadlifts for stability and longevity when done properly [27:30] From episode: #103 – Looking back on the first 99 episodes: Strong Convictions, Loosely Held; discussed from [42:00] – [51:00] How has Peter’s thinking changed on deadlifts? Long before powerlifting was in vogue, Peter would lift weights every day with a friend in high school  Powerlifting is different from olympic lifting, powerlifting is 3 lifts: the deadlift, the squat, and the bench press Peter grew up doing a lot of deadlift, squatting, and bench pressing He was always horrible at the bench press In 2016 Peter partially tore one of his obliques After this he was never able to deadlift again without some discomfort Even though it is a great total hip hinge, compound movement, he got away from doing deadlifts This changed when he began Dynamic Neuromuscular Stimulation (DNS) in 2017/ 2018 Learn more about DNS in these episodes of The Drive:  #131 – Beth Lewis: The Art of Stability: Learning about pain, mitigating injury, and moving better through life  #152 – Michael Rintala, D.C.: Principles of Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) ) Through DNS Peter realized the deadlift was going to be beneficial because it becomes a beautiful audit for everything working perfectly Peter deadlifts at least twice a week (often 3x a week), both straight bar and trap bar; he doesn’t go that heavy In terms of weight for deadlifts, Peter might have had 400 lbs on the trap bar in the past year He usually stops at 350-375 on the trap bar On the straight bar he goes lighter, maybe 185 lbs He does a lot of slow eccentrics He films every single rep of every set He studies it and sends it to his coach, Beth Lewis He works to make his deadlift perfect “I’d rather take a light weight and deadlift it perfectly several times per week”‒ Peter Attia  His typical workout is 4-5 sets of 10 reps  These are not killing, crusher sets At no point is he past his limit He can push himself harder in other things Peter’s goal is to do the deadlift perfectly, and he is constantly checking his form  Does he have just the right amount of thoracic extension? Does he have just the right curvature in the lumbar spine? Does he activate his glutes?  Does he activate his hamstrings? Is he pulling back instead of pulling up? Is he wedging correctly? “All of this little stuff translates biomechanically to the activities of daily living that matter to me.  Like getting up off the floor, picking up one of my kids, lifting a piece of luggage, or something like that.”‒ Peter Attia If he can do the deadlift and it feels right, then he knows he ready to do everything correctly When something doesn’t feel right during a deadlift, he knows 1 – How to recognize that feeling 2 – The steps to bo back and correct it Peter wants to put together a video on deadlift and preparation There are about 10 exercises he does to get ready to deadlift; they don’t take long (10-15 minutes) He’s not sure how much of the benefit is the actual deadlift versus all the things he does to do the deadlift correctly Only recently did Peter realize you can deadlift in a way that puts your spine under traction This is counterintuitive; you might think your spine is under compression when lifting under an axial load It turns out when you learn the right positioning, then you can deadlift and actively create traction in the spine You understand how to create intra-abdominal pressure You know how to elongate your spine This is why the deadlift is the most important thing Peter does before he gets on an airplane He’s going to be sitting for 5-6 hours He doesn’t want his spine to be compressed The deadlift primes him to maintain that activated form of traction   The importance of zone 2 aerobic training [35:45] From episode #103 – Looking back on the first 99 episodes: Strong Convictions, Loosely Held; discussed from [37:00] – [41:00] Zone 2 training has been covered in a variety of episodes; this was most recently covered in the second podcast with Iñigo San-Millán #201 – Deep dive back into Zone 2 | Iñigo San-Millán, Ph.D. (Pt. 2) Peter spends 3-4 hours per week training in zone 2 and thinks it’s incredibly important for all of his patients You want to put a rate-limiter on the intensity of your workout when you do zone 2 training How has Peter’s thinking on zone 2 training changed? When Peter was a cyclist, he spent 10-12 hours a week training in zone 2 Now he spends 3-4 hours per week in this zone In late 2014 when Peter stopped competing in time trials, he stopped doing any low intensity training (which is a major component of training for competition) He went from cycling to rowing and running He was obsessed with being as efficient as possible; everything was an all-out effort If he was running, it would be a 6-minute mile, not a 9-minute mile Meeting Iñigo and going through literature on zone 2 training before having him on the podcast brought to light the benefits of this type of training Metabolic benefits‒ insulin-dependent and insulin-independent glucose disposal Improvement of mitochondrial function, health, and density Increased release of neurotrophic factors that can come from this type of activity, such as BDNF secretion Peter realized he needed to reincorporate zone 2 training into his exercise program “One of the things about zone 2 that I really enjoy is, it’s just not that hard… it’s just nice to get on the bike… and that’s my time to listen to podcasts and audiobooks”‒ Peter Attia Takeaway: We can do zone 2 our entire lives; we can do it safely, and it yields enormous dividends   The most effective ways to engage in zone 2 exercise [40:00] The next clip is from episode #145 – AMA #19: Deep dive on Zone 2 training, magnesium supplementation, and how to engage with your doctor; discussed from  [14:00] – [18:30] There is not a best device, but choose one where you can easily reproduce the same output Peter likes the bicycle because it has a clear metric that he can adjust‒ the wattage Watts are easy to track He uses an ergometer; he puts his road bike on a device called a Wahoo KICKR which is hooked up to a computer where he sets the numbers of watts he wants and it adjusts the resistance  Peter on his Wahoo KICKR explaining a zone 2 workout:  Other devices can be good for zone 2 training His wife likes to ride a Peloton (he doesn’t like it); she doesn’t got into a class but sets the resistance and the RPM she puts in, and it spits out a wattage So she has to adjust her cadence to stay at a specific wattage It’s the difference between in erg-mode and spin-mode She also likes a rowing machine Peter is not fond of rowing for zone 2 He likes the rowing machine for zone 5, but that’s because he’s not a very good rower  Someone who has good form (like Beth Lewis, previously on the podcast) can get a good zone 2 workout on a rowing machine Cycling is second nature for Peter; it’s a very efficient thing for him to do He’s not fond of ellipticals because it’s hard to stay in the proper zone You may have one that works for you, where you can get your heart rate high enough and move quick enough The key is‒ how much energy do you have to put in to maintain a sustained dose?  The bike on the erg-mode of a trainer makes it easy; he doesn’t have to think about it; it’s putting 200 watts to his wheel no matter what he does in terms of speed Regardless of the device, it’s the wattage that matters He is also always measuring heart rate  Treadmills are also a great way to do this For most people though, running gets them out of zone 2 quickly  He advises patients to do brisk, incline walking  Start at a 10-15-degree incline at 2.5-3.0 miles per hour (maybe less) This is empirical, you have to figure out what incline and speed will keep you in zone 2 How do you know you’re in zone 2? Track power output (watts), heart rate, and lactate Peter has noticed his heart rate will be elevated if he’s sick, dehydrated, or something In this case back off; adjust the wattage down a bit   Zone 5 training and VO2 max [44:15] From episode #153 – AMA #21: Deep dive into olive oil, high-intensity exercise, book update, and more; discussed from [49:30] – [55:30] Another pillar of Peter’s framework of exercise focuses on the upper end of aerobic, verging on anaerobic exercise (zone 5 training) Zones are a function of the underlying system used to track exercise intensity This could be heart rate-based training  Or power-based training (following wattage output) Peter thinks of zone 5 as VO2 max training We talk about VO2 max in AMA #27 and compare someone with low fitness (at the bottom 25% of VO2 max) to someone with elite fitness (at the top 2.5% VO2 max) There is about a 5-fold difference in benefit between these 2 groups This shows the importance of VO2 max People often spend too little or too much time in zone 5 This discussion will help you determine what that sweet-spot is  This assumes that you are not training specifically for competition or athletic events that require unusual levels of fitness around the zone 5 energy system If you are training to be a kick ass 90-year-old, then you don’t need to spend as much time in zone 5 as you might think What is Peter’s approach to zone 5 training and other anaerobic training protocols? Peter mostly uses the stairmaster for his zone 5 training This is his favorite piece of equipment other than the bicycle He does 1 zone 5 workout a week‒ 3 minutes of zone 2 1 minute at VO2 max (this is quite difficult to keep this up for 1 minute) Repeat this 4-minute pattern for 20-30 minutes He does this on the tail-end of a zone 2 workout; so this is his longer aerobic day Because he knows what his VO2 max is, he can convert it into METS (Metabolic equivalent of task) The stairmaster allows you to work at watts and METS When he’s outdoors on his bike, he likes to do a training-type/ VO2 max ride 4 minutes at 125% FTP (functional threshold power) Followed by 4 minutes of recovery There’s lots of ways to hit zone 5 but Peter’s take is that most people spend too much time in zone 5 and not enough time in zone 2 More about Peter’s stairmaster machine He uses a fancy one like they have at the gym; it has a series of steps that rotate (similar to #4 & #8 on this list)  The higher the intensity, the less resistance it provides; this makes you climb the steps faster At 8 METS he steps quite slowly At 20 METS it feels like there is no resistance and he’s running up the steps If you’re working 100% (balls-to-the-wall), you can exceed your VO2 max in terms of the work you’re doing Alex Hutchinson writes about this in his book Endure  Alex was also the guest for episode #151 – Alex Hutchinson, Ph.D.: Translating the science of endurance and extreme human performance Alex Hutchinson elegantly writes‒ the limits of human performance in terms of going all out, is about 10 seconds  You may think you’re going all out for 80% of a spin class, but you’re not Consider the difference between a 100 m and a 200 m sprint, run by the best athletes on the planet By the time Usain Bolt is running the 200 m, he is slowing down in the second half of the race The 100 m is about a 10-second race; this is about the limit of what a true all-out-effort means Consider 2 variants of Tabata:  1 – The 20:10 Tabata (seconds of strenuous exercise: seconds of rest) 2 – The 10:20 Tabata Anyone who has tried this knows you can go so much harder for the 10:20 than the 20:10 Peter likes to use an Airbike for Tabata exercise  The 20:10 Tabata is favored because this is the one that was studied by Irisawa and Tabata  Irsiawa developed the protocol and Tabata wrote the paper  This should be called the Irsiawas instead of the Tabata Published in BMC in 2019, Tabata training: one of the most energetically effective high-intensity intermittent training methods The problem with the 20:10 Tabata is you’re actually pacing yourself (whether consciously or subconsciously)   A primer on VO2 max [52:00] This next clip is from episode #151 – Alex Hutchinson, Ph.D.: Translating the science of endurance and extreme human performance; discussed from [38:00] – [49:30] An analogy to think about VO2 max is‒ VO2 max is like the size of your engine  Physiologically, VO2 max tells you how quickly you can take oxygen from the air, into your lungs, get it into your blood, pump it to your muscles, and have your muscles use it in the metabolic processes that provide energy to move you  VO2 max is a rate; it’s how much oxygen per unit of time can you process   VO2 max was first discussed/measured in the 1920s by a guy named A.V. Hill, a very good runner himself If you ask someone to go out and run at a gentle pace, let’s say they consume 2 liters of oxygen per minute Tell them to speed up, and now they’re doing 3 liters of oxygen per minute Tell them to speed up again, and now they’re going really fast and they’re losing 4 liters of oxygen per minute Tell them to speed up again, and they are still only using 4 liters of oxygen a minute In other words, there’s a plateau‒ a point at which, even though you’re working harder, you’re not using any more oxygen; this is one’s VO2 max  This plateau looks like a physiological limitation This is a point where, no matter how much you push yourself, you can’t get more oxygen (even though you can still go faster using other forms of energy) This is the limits of your aerobic system  This doesn’t tell you how fast you can run “That [VO2 max] tells you what sort of aerobic engine you have to play with”‒ Alex Hutchinson People are used to hearing VO2 max reported, not in liters per minute but mL per min per kg Examples of VO2 max  An outlier VO2 max is a number bigger than 2 L or 5 L; this would be 75 or 80 mL Alex (a runner) was tested at just over 5 L/min If you compared him to a rower, the rower would make him look pathetic because the rower would be using 7 L/min or more A rower is also twice his size, so this doesn’t mean that the rower is better because he has way more muscle to use the oxygen he’s taking in If you want to compare apples-to-apples (athletes of different sizes), for a crude approximation, you divide by weight This is reported as milliliters of oxygen per minute per kilogram of body weight For Alex, 5 L/ min works out to 80 mL/min∙kg For Peter who also measured at around 5L/min, he is heavier so this worked out to around 70 mL/min∙kg You could argue that you should divide by lean mass not total body weight to account for skeletal tissue, fat, etc. as the amount of these tissues can vary but they doesn’t use more oxygen during exercise There’s a whole rabbit hole you can go into, but at a certain point it doesn’t matter that much For comparing to yourself, to see if you’ve increased your VO2 max, it doesn’t matter what you’re dividing by “You can’t just measure someone’s VO2 max and know how fast they’re going to race”‒ Alex Hutchinson When Peter was cycling competitively, there was a guy he would ride with whose VO2 max was 55-60 mL/min∙kg (Peter’s was 70 mL/min∙kg); but there was never a day where Peter could ride faster than him Maybe his friend was a more efficient athlete  Historical limits of VO2 max‒ what is it that causes VO2 max to plateau?    There is a lot of confusion and debate about the limits of VO2 max  If you want to measure endurance by testing how fast someone can run a mile as hard as they can, but there are many factors that can affect this Motivation, pacing, lots of factors The nice thing about VO2 max (and why scientists like it) is, in theory it’s independent of motivation The plateau in oxygen intake is a property of their body and not a result of if they’re excited about the study/ exercise The cause of this plateau could be in the lungs, in the heart, in the circulation, or in the muscle’s ability to extract oxygen from the bloodstream and make use of it metabolically in the mitochondria This is controversial and limitations can arise in any part of this cascade  Conventional wisdom is that the lungs are not the limitation, you can always breathe enough in and they don’t respond to training because they’re overbuilt But a review was published arguing that in some cases (such as highly-trained endurance athletes), the lungs aren’t overbuilt and can be a limitation on VO2 max Published in the Journal of Applied Physiology in 1985, Is the healthy respiratory system built just right, overbuilt, or underbuilt to meet the demands imposed by exercise? There is also the situation where an athlete is so fit, their heart pumps blood so quickly past their lungs, that it doesn’t have time to fully stock-up on oxygen This results in exercise-induced arterial hypoxemia  This is usually an issue at altitude About half of endurance athletes experience this at sea level There is debate on this because there isn’t any 1 single answer; limits of VO2 max can occur anywhere along the cascade of taking oxygen in and the muscle using it in the production of energy  Peter notes that the way the oxygen consumption is calculated relies on measuring the oxygen concentration breathed out and calculating the difference (the delta) between that and the oxygen concentration in the air (breathed in)   It would be interesting to test VO2 max while reducing the FIO2 (the fraction of inspired oxygen) To put this in context, the typical FIO2 in any room is 21% oxygen If FIO2 was reduced to 20%, 19%, 18%, etc. and if the lungs are not the limitation for VO2 max, then you should see the same  VO2 max (or measure the same absolute delta between inhaled versus exhaled oxygen) in all of these conditions of different oxygen % This would be an interesting experiment to eliminate lungs and capillary exchange of oxygen as a limit on VO2 max Alex doesn’t think a study this detailed has been published People have compared 21% oxygen to 10% and 15% oxygen Less oxygen is available at altitude and funny things happen You would think that the first thing to happen is, you would go anaerobic sooner and produce more lactate; but the opposite happens This is called the lactate paradox If you exercise to exhaustion at lower levels of altitude, you produce less lactate than you would a sea level There’s debate over what causes this and if it’s a real thing “The picture that makes sense to me is, these things are not just about how much oxygen is making it to the muscle, it’s also‒ what is your brain-oxygen level”‒ Alex Hutchinson There are these other circuit-breakers limiting VO2 max, that aren’t on the path from mouth to lung, to blood, to muscle There are other factors that detect low oxygen and cut off the supply to the muscle to make sure we don’t get stupid [deprive the brain of oxygen]   Stability—the cornerstone upon which all exercise and movement relies [1:03:00] This clip is from episode #92 – AMA #12: Strategies for longevity (which don’t require a doctor); discussed from [24:30] – [29:00] Peter along with Beth Lewis and Michael Rintala filmed instructional videos showing how to do various exercises  Peter can’t recommend them enough It’s one thing to hear talk about the exercises, it’s quite another thing to see them and be able to do them yourself Videos from Peter:  Hip hinge (VMO): Deadlifts:  Scapulae:  Concentric intra-abdominal pressure (to stabilize the ribs): The importance of stability “Stability is the cornerstone upon which your strength is delivered, your aerobic performance is delivered, and your anaerobic performance is delivered.  And it’s the way that you do so safely”‒ Peter Attia Stability is the way that we transmit force from the body to the outside world  In the safest manner possible Across the muscles which are designed to carry that load This is opposed to seeing the dissipation of force across joints that are not fit to do so Consider picking up something that weighs 60 lbs, you have to exert 60 lbs of force on the world around you (according to Newton’s Laws) You want all of that 60 lbs to be transmitted from your muscle, to the ground, to this thing you are picking up You don’t want anything dissipating out your back, knees, or hips  Most of us are born with the ability to do this naturally, but it generally gets lost by the time we begin grade school  Why? A relative lack of activity and an abundance of sitting When Peter looks at his  2 ½ year old move, it’s a perfect clinic in force transmission safely across the body If you look at Peter move, prior to becoming obsessed with dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS), you see inefficiencies and force leakage (at his scapula, his knee, his elbow, his back, his hips  This is one of the root causes of a lot of the chronic injuries many of us have  Stability is the foundation upon which all exercise should be done Recently Peter discussed this with a patient who had a question‒ should she do DNS or continue with the pilates she’s done for many years?  A great pilates teacher is already teaching many of these principles Stability is somewhat discipline agnostic but heavily dependant on the practitioner and the student  The correct patterns of movement are characterized by the ability to:  1 – Get air fully into your lungs 2 – Get your diaphragm low into your abdomen 3 – Flatten out your pelvic floor 4 – Generate concentric, robust, intra abdominal pressure that stabilizes every aspect of them Postural restoration (PRI), DNS, and pilates are all different ways one can learn these principles of stability “Of the 4 pieces of exercise that we will talk about, this is the one [stability] that probably will take the most tinkering for people to find the right type of practitioners”‒ Peter Attia   Peter’s current exercise routine [1:07:45] From episode #196 – AMA #32: Exercise, squats, deadlifts, BFR, and TRT; discussed from [3:00] – [6:00] In this last clip Peter talks about the macro structure of his current exercise routine The macrostructure hasn’t changed much in the last year The microstructure (exercises) has changed a lot  Cardio days‒ Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday, Sunday  45 minutes of zone 2 training on Tuesday, Thursday, Sunday Saturday is 1 of the following: A zone 2 workout (45”) followed by zone 5 workout (30”) A longer bike ride, more of an anaerobic workout  Weightlifting‒ Monday, Wednesday, Friday, Sunday 9 months ago, he switched to an upper body/ lower body split He used to lift 3 days a week, and do upper body and lower body everyday Now he does lower body on Mondays and Fridays, and he does upper body on Wednesdays and Sundays He always lifts AFTER doing cardio because the reverse has been shown to erode strength-training gains  What happens if you miss a day? Last Sunday was supposed to be a cardio/ ride followed by a lift day; but he was on the track all day He knew that in advance, so he did the lift on Saturday But he was short-changed on the zone 2 workout He will never compromise a lift; he will always get 4 lifts in per week Sometimes it means moving the days around or doubling-up on another day Do you have a preference for the time of day to exercise? Monday – Friday, this happens in the morning once the kids are out the door, off to school The weekends are more flexible §Selected Links / Related MaterialWhat is Peter optimizing for with his exercise: #92 – AMA #12: Strategies for longevity (which don’t require a doctor) | Host Peter Attia, The Peter Attia Drive Podcast (February 10, 2020) |  discussed from [30:30 – 33:45] How to train for the “Centenarian Decathlon”: #50 – AMA #5: calcium scores, Centenarian Decathlon, exercise, muscle glycogen, keto, and more | Host Peter Attia, The Peter Attia Drive Podcast (April 22, 2019) | discussed from [18:15 – 33:45] Study of genetics of centenarians:  Institute for Aging Research:  Longevity Genes Project | Albert Einstein College of Medicine | [20:15] BU School of Medicine:  New England Centenarian Study | Boston University | [20:15] The importance of preserving strength and muscle mass as we age: #176 – AMA #27: The importance of muscle mass, strength, and cardiorespiratory fitness for longevity | Host Peter Attia, The Peter Attia Drive Podcast (September 20, 2021) | discussed from [58:00 – 1:03:30] Review of loss of lean muscle and strength due to aging: Strength and muscle mass loss with aging process.
